text:
[music playing]
- Merry Christmas, Cricket.

What do you think
you got from Santa?
I don't know, Tilly.

I just hope this sign made
it clear I do not want coal.
Coal?

Trust me, that ain't
going to happen again.
Again?

Yep, it's time for a
Broken Karaoke that'll teach
you the truth about Santa.

He was once my
sworn mortal enemy.

(SINGING) Santa gave my
grandson coal for Christmas.

He made my little
angel's heart just break.

But your Gramma is not
some weak old lady.

And Santa made a
very grave mistake.

- Oh, my!
- What'd you do, Gramma?

GRAMMA: (SINGING) So I
headed to the North Pole.

I snuck a ride on
the Polar Express.

There I met a talking
snowman, and I made him give
up old Saint Nick's address.
Uh, did this really happen?

GRAMMA: (SINGING) I broke
into Santa's toy shop,

and it was filled with
all these stinking elves.

I said, take me to the
big guy, and they refused,
so we battled until twelve.
TILLY: You attacked the elves?

GRAMMA: (SINGING) Santa gave
my grandson coal for Christmas.

How dare he try to
turn me my own kin!

I'd love to cook up
Christmas trees for Santa

and serve him up the
reindeer in a tin.
What happened next?

GRAMMA: (SINGING) I came
face to face with Santa as he
gave Rudolph a new hairdo.
Hey, jerk!
You drive like that my grandson.

I'd say that naughty
person here is you.
CRICKET: Silk-wearing Gramma.

GRAMMA: (SINGING) Santa
Claus looked so remorseful,

and I must admit
that I was floored.

He said he was deeply
sorry, then he gifted
me his own grandmother's sword.

TILLY: That's how
you got your sword?

GRAMMA: (SINGING) Then I gave
my grandson coal for Christmas,

but he vowed he
won't do that again.

Once a year I go back to
the North Pole because me

and Santa Claus are
now best friends.
Sing it, kids.

(SINGING) Santa gave her
grandson coal for Christmas,

so she gave him a
piece of her mind.

No more coal, we better
skip the presents,

or Gramma shall not
dare put this behind.
Merry Christmas.
